greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Length of the complete Cunningham chain of the second kind starting with prime(n), or -1 if the chain has infinite length.
comment: Number of iterations x -> 2x-1 needed to get a composite number, when starting with prime(n), or -1 if a composite number is never reached.
Dickson's conjecture implies that, for every positive integer r, there exist infinitely many n such that a(n) = r. - _Lorenzo Sauras Altuzarra_, Feb 12 2021
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
G. Löh, Long chains of nearly doubled primes, Math. Comp., 53 (1989), 751-759.
Michael Penn, Romanian Mathematical Olympiad Problem, Youtube video, 2020.
formula: a(n) < prime(n) for n > 1; see Löh (1989), p. 751. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Oct 28 2015
max(a(n), A181697(n)) = A263879(n) for n > 2. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Oct 30 2015
example: 2 -> 3 -> 5 -> 9 = 3^2, so a(1) = 3 and a(2) = 2. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Oct 30 2015
maple: while isprime(l) do c, l := c+1, 2*l-1: od:
mathematica: Table[p = Prime[n]; cnt = 1; While[p = 2*p - 1; PrimeQ[p], cnt++]; cnt, {n, 100}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Jul 12 2012 *)
Table[-1 + Length@ NestWhileList[2 # - 1 &, Prime@ n, PrimeQ@ # &], {n, 98}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Apr 26 2017 *)
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Nov 17 2010
ext: Escape clause added to definition by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Feb 19 2021
